Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: High Performance Filesystems and Data Visualization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Simulations of galactic events such as black hole and galaxy mergers <br/>allow scientists to understand the fundamental nature of the universe. <br/>These simulations create terabytes of data, which are extremely difficult <br/>and time consuming to analyze using traditional mathematical tools and <br/>techniques. To address these challenges, scientists often use data <br/>visualization, which provides a powerful and effective approach to <br/>understand interactions and behavior of simulations such as visualizing <br/>the radiation of gravity waves during a supermassive black hole merger. <br/>Visualization systems require high performance file-systems for efficient <br/>data management. Over the last three years, a collaborative effort <br/>between the Computer Science Department and the Center for Computational <br/>Relativity and Gravitation at Rochester Institute of Technology resulted <br/>in a visualization framework called Spiegel that has been used successfully <br/>to analyze and visualize the simulation of a variety of galactic events.<br/><br/>This REU site provides students with the opportunity, environment and support <br/>to conduct research in data visualization and high-performance file systems <br/>using Spiegel as the starting point. Working in a collaborative and <br/>interdisciplinary environment, students develop solutions to a broad set <br/>of research problems in performing computation on massive amounts of <br/>multi-dimensional data. Consequently, students gain knowledge in understanding, <br/>critiquing, and presenting research literature. This project offers students <br/>opportunities to work on state-of-the-art computing techniques that are <br/>increasingly vital for solving research problems in modern scientific <br/>disciplines. Undergraduate students are encouraged to pursue interdisciplinary <br/>graduate studies in STEM disciplines. With specific recruiting efforts that <br/>target underrepresented groups such as women, minorities, and persons with <br/>disabilities, especially deaf and hard-of-hearing students, this REU program <br/>also aims to increase the size and diversity of the scientific workforce.<br/>
